title: Common Structures
description: Master common English patterns for expressing ideas, feelings, and relationships between concepts.

children.title: Would you like...?
children.contentHTML:
Would you like...?

Used to make polite offers and invitations.

  • Would you like + to + Verb?
    Example: Would you like to join us for dinner?
  • Would you like + Noun?
    Example: Would you like some coffee?

children.title: Would rather
children.contentHTML:
Would rather

Used to express a preference for one thing over another.

S + would rather + Verb (base) + (than + Verb (base))

Example: I would rather stay home than go to the movies.

children.title: Prefer
children.contentHTML:
Prefer

Used to state a general preference.

  • S + prefer + Noun + to + Noun
    Example: I prefer tea to coffee.
  • S + prefer + V-ing + to + V-ing
    Example: She prefers reading to watching TV.

children.title: Let / Let's
children.contentHTML:
Let / Let's

  • Let's: Used to make a suggestion that includes the speaker.
    Let's + Verb (base)
    Example: Let's go to the beach.
  • Let: Used to give permission.
    Let + Object + Verb (base)
    Example: My mom let me use her car.

children.title: Suggest
children.contentHTML:
Suggest

Used to propose an idea or plan.

  • S + suggest + V-ing
    Example: He suggested going for a walk.
  • S + suggest + (that) + S + Verb (base) (Subjunctive)
    Example: I suggest that you be on time.

children.title: Hope
children.contentHTML:
Hope

Used to express a desire for something to happen.

S + hope + (that) + S + V (present/future)

Example: I hope you have a great trip.

children.title: Advise
children.contentHTML:
Advise

Used to give advice or a recommendation.

S + advise + Object + to + Verb

Example: The doctor advised him to rest.

children.title: Promise
children.contentHTML:
Promise

Used to make a commitment to do something.

S + promise + to + Verb

Example: She promised to call me later.

children.title: Ask
children.contentHTML:
Ask

Used to make a request.

S + ask + Object + to + Verb

Example: I asked him to close the door.

children.title: Had better
children.contentHTML:
Had better

Used to give strong advice, often implying a negative consequence if the advice is not followed.

S + had better + Verb (base)

Example: You had better finish your work or the boss will be angry.

children.title: Need
children.contentHTML:
Need

Used to express necessity.

  • Active: S + need + to + Verb
    Example: I need to buy groceries.
  • Passive Meaning: S + need + V-ing
    Example: The car needs washing. (= The car needs to be washed.)

children.title: Verbs followed by Gerund (V-ing)
children.contentHTML:
Verbs followed by Gerund (V-ing)

Many verbs describing likes, dislikes, and attitudes are followed by a gerund.

  • enjoy: I enjoy reading books.
  • avoid: You should avoid eating junk food.
  • mind: Would you mind opening the window?

children.title: Refuse
children.contentHTML:
Refuse

Used to say you will not do something. It is followed by an infinitive (to + Verb).

S + refuse + to + Verb

Example: The child refused to eat his vegetables.

children.title: Regret
children.contentHTML:
Regret

The meaning changes depending on what follows.

  • regret + V-ing (to be sorry about something you did in the past)
    Example: I regret telling her my secret.
  • regret + to + Verb (to be sorry to give bad news)
    Example: We regret to inform you that your application was unsuccessful.

children.title: Stop
children.contentHTML:
Stop

The meaning changes depending on what follows.

  • stop + V-ing (to quit an action)
    Example: He stopped smoking last year.
  • stop + to + Verb (to pause an activity in order to do something else)
    Example: We stopped to get some coffee on our way.

children.title: find it + adjective + to V
children.contentHTML:
find it + adjective + to V

Used to express an opinion about an action.

S + find + it + adjective + to + Verb

Example: I find it difficult to understand this topic.

children.title: Although / Despite / In spite of
children.contentHTML:
Although / Despite / In spite of

Used to show contrast.

  • Although + Clause (S + V)
    Example: Although it was raining, we went for a walk.
  • Despite / In spite of + Noun / V-ing
    Example: Despite the rain, we went for a walk.
    Example: In spite of feeling tired, he finished the race.

children.title: Because / Because of
children.contentHTML:
Because / Because of

Used to show a reason or cause.

  • Because + Clause (S + V)
    Example: He was late because there was heavy traffic.
  • Because of + Noun / V-ing
    Example: He was late because of the heavy traffic.

children.title: So / Such / Too
children.contentHTML:
So / Such / Too (Result & Degree)

  • so + adj/adv + that + Clause
    Example: It was so cold that we stayed inside.
  • such + (a/an) + adj + Noun + that + Clause
    Example: It was such a cold day that we stayed inside.
  • too + adj/adv + (for someone) + to + Verb
    Example: The coffee is too hot to drink.

children.title: Not only ... but also
children.contentHTML:
Not only ... but also

A correlative conjunction used to emphasize two related pieces of information.

Example: She is not only intelligent but also very kind.

children.title: As well as
children.contentHTML:
As well as

Means 'in addition to'.

Noun/V-ing + as well as + Noun/V-ing

Example: He plays the guitar as well as the piano.
Example: She is good at singing as well as dancing.

children.title: It was not until ... that
children.contentHTML:
It was not until ... that

An emphatic structure used to highlight when something happened.

It was not until + time/event + that + S + V (past simple)

Example: It was not until I got home that I realized I had lost my keys.

children.title: When / While / After
children.contentHTML:
Time Conjunctions: When / While / After

  • When: Refers to a specific point in time. (Call me when you arrive.)
  • While: Refers to a duration of time. (He read a book while he was waiting.)
  • After: Refers to a sequence of events. (We'll talk after I finish my work.)

children.title: Used to / Be used to
children.contentHTML:
Used to / Be used to

  • used to + Verb (base) (a past habit that is no longer true)
    Example: I used to play basketball in high school.
  • be used to + V-ing (to be accustomed to something)
    Example: I am used to waking up early.

children.title: Remember
children.contentHTML:
Remember

The meaning changes depending on what follows.

  • remember + V-ing (to recall a memory from the past)
    Example: I remember meeting him for the first time.
  • remember + to + Verb (to not forget to do something)
    Example: Please remember to lock the door.

children.title: Unless
children.contentHTML:
Unless

A conditional conjunction that means 'if...not'.

Unless + Clause (present) , ... Clause (future)

Example: You will fail the test unless you study. (= ...if you don't study.)

children.title: Enough
children.contentHTML:
Enough

Used to indicate sufficiency.

  • adjective/adverb + enough + (for someone) + to + Verb
    Example: He is not old enough to vote.
  • enough + Noun + (for someone) + to + Verb
    Example: We don't have enough money to buy a car.

children.title: Impersonal 'It' Structures
children.contentHTML:
Impersonal 'It' Structures

The pronoun 'it' can be used as an impersonal subject to make general statements or comments, especially about actions.

It + be + adjective + (for someone) + to + Verb

Example: It is difficult to learn a new language.
Example: It's important for you to be on time.

grammarQuestions.prompt: It's getting late. You ___ go now or you'll miss the last bus.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Had better' is a fixed structure used for strong advice or a warning about negative consequences.

grammarQuestions.prompt: He stopped ___ a cigarette because he was feeling tired.
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'stop to smoke' means he paused his current activity in order to have a cigarette. 'stop smoking' means to quit the habit.

grammarQuestions.prompt: Which of these words/phrases must be followed by a noun or a gerund (V-ing)?
grammarQuestions.explanation: 'Despite' and 'in spite of' are prepositions and must be followed by a noun phrase or gerund. 'Although' and 'because' are conjunctions that introduce a full clause (Subject + Verb).
